t: Song of Solomon 1
The*p Song of Songs, which is Solomon’s.
The Bride Confesses Her Love
She
Let*pn him kiss me with the kisses of his mouth! For*ln your love is better than wine;
your*ld anointing oils are fragrant; your*ln name is oil poured out; therefore*ld virgins love you.
Draw*ln me after you; let us run. The*ld king has brought me into his chambers.
Others
We*pn will exult and rejoice in you; we*ld will extol your love more than wine; rightly*ld do they love you.
She
I*pn am very dark, but lovely, O*ld daughters of Jerusalem, like*ln the tents of Kedar, like*ld the curtains of Solomon.
Do*ln not gaze at me because I am dark, because*ld the sun has looked upon me. My*ln mother’s sons were angry with me; they*ld made me keeper of the vineyards, but*ld my own vineyard I have not kept!
Tell*ln me, you whom my soul loves, where*ld you pasture your flock, where*ld you make it lie down at noon; for*ln why should I be like one who veils herself beside*ld the flocks of your companions?
Solomon and His Bride Delight in Each Other
He
If*pn you do not know, O*ld most beautiful among women, follow*ln in the tracks of the flock, and*ld pasture your young goats beside*ld the shepherds’ tents.
I*pn compare you, my love, to*ld a mare among Pharaoh’s chariots.
Your*ln cheeks are lovely with ornaments, your*ld neck with strings of jewels.
Others
We*pn will make for you ornaments of gold, studded*ld with silver.
She
While*pn the king was on his couch, my*ld nard gave forth its fragrance.
My*ln beloved is to me a sachet of myrrh that*ld lies between my breasts.
My*ln beloved is to me a cluster of henna blossoms in*ld the vineyards of Engedi.
He
Behold,*pn you are beautiful, my love; behold,*ld you are beautiful; your*ld eyes are doves.
She
Behold,*pn you are beautiful, my beloved, truly delightful. Our*ln couch is green;
the*ld beams of our house are cedar; our*ld rafters are pine.
Song of Solomon 2
I*pn am a rose of Sharon, a*ld lily of the valleys.
He
As*pn a lily among brambles, so*ld is my love among the young women.
She
As*pn an apple tree among the trees of the forest, so*ld is my beloved among the young men. With*ln great delight I sat in his shadow, and*ld his fruit was sweet to my taste.
He*ln brought me to the banqueting house, and*ld his banner over me was love.
Sustain*ln me with raisins; refresh*ld me with apples, for*ld I am sick with love.
His*ln left hand is under my head, and*ld his right hand embraces me!
I*ln adjure you, O daughters of Jerusalem, by*ld the gazelles or the does of the field, that*ln you not stir up or awaken love until*ld it pleases.
The Bride Adores Her Beloved
The*pn voice of my beloved! Behold,*ld he comes, leaping*ln over the mountains, bounding*ld over the hills.
My*ln beloved is like a gazelle or*ld a young stag. Behold,*ln there he stands behind*ld our wall, gazing*ln through the windows, looking*ld through the lattice.
My*ln beloved speaks and says to me: “Arise,*ln my love, my beautiful one, and*ld come away,
for*ln behold, the winter is past; the*ld rain is over and gone.
The*ln flowers appear on the earth, the*ld time of singing has come, and*ln the voice of the turtledove is*ld heard in our land.
The*ln fig tree ripens its figs, and*ld the vines are in blossom; they*ld give forth fragrance. Arise,*ln my love, my beautiful one, and*ld come away.
O*ln my dove, in the clefts of the rock, in*ld the crannies of the cliff, let*ln me see your face, let*ld me hear your voice, for*ln your voice is sweet, and*ld your face is lovely.
Catch*ln the foxes for us, the*ld little foxes that*ln spoil the vineyards, for*ld our vineyards are in blossom.”
My*pn beloved is mine, and I am his; he*ld grazes among the lilies.
Until*ln the day breathes and*ld the shadows flee, turn,*ln my beloved, be like a gazelle or*ld a young stag on cleft mountains.
Song of Solomon 3
The Bride’s Dream
On*pn my bed by night I*ln sought him whom my soul loves; I*ld sought him, but found him not.
I*ln will rise now and go about the city, in*ld the streets and in the squares; I*ln will seek him whom my soul loves. I*ld sought him, but found him not.
The*ln watchmen found me as*ld they went about in the city. “Have*ln you seen him whom my soul loves?”

Scarcely*ln had I passed them when*ld I found him whom my soul loves. I*ln held him, and would not let him go until*ld I had brought him into my mother’s house, and*ld into the chamber of her who conceived me.
I*ln adjure you, O daughters of Jerusalem, by*ld the gazelles or the does of the field, that*ln you not stir up or awaken love until*ld it pleases.
Solomon Arrives for the Wedding
What*pn is that coming up from the wilderness like*ld columns of smoke, perfumed*ln with myrrh and frankincense, with*ld all the fragrant powders of a merchant?
Behold,*ln it is the litter of Solomon! Around*ln it are sixty mighty men, some*ld of the mighty men of Israel,
all*ln of them wearing swords and*ld expert in war, each*ln with his sword at his thigh, against*ld terror by night.
King*ln Solomon made himself a carriage from*ld the wood of Lebanon.
He*ln made its posts of silver, its*ld back of gold, its seat of purple; its*ln interior was inlaid with love by*ld the daughters of Jerusalem.
Go*ln out, O daughters of Zion, and*ld look upon King Solomon, with*ln the crown with which his mother crowned him on*ld the day of his wedding, on*ld the day of the gladness of his heart.
Song of Solomon 4
Solomon Admires His Bride’s Beauty
He
Behold,*pn you are beautiful, my love, behold,*ld you are beautiful! Your*ln eyes are doves behind*ld your veil. Your*ln hair is like a flock of goats leaping*ld down the slopes of Gilead.
Your*ln teeth are like a flock of shorn ewes that*ld have come up from the washing, all*ln of which bear twins, and*ld not one among them has lost its young.
Your*ln lips are like a scarlet thread, and*ld your mouth is lovely. Your*ln cheeks are like halves of a pomegranate behind*ld your veil.
Your*ln neck is like the tower of David, built*ld in rows of stone; on*ln it hang a thousand shields, all*ld of them shields of warriors.
Your*ln two breasts are like two fawns, twins*ld of a gazelle, that*ld graze among the lilies.
Until*ln the day breathes and*ld the shadows flee, I*ln will go away to the mountain of myrrh and*ld the hill of frankincense.
You*ln are altogether beautiful, my love; there*ld is no flaw in you.

Come*ln with me from Lebanon, my bride; come*ld with me from Lebanon. Depart*ln from the peak of Amana, from*ld the peak of Senir and Hermon, from*ln the dens of lions, from*ld the mountains of leopards.
You*pn have captivated my heart, my sister, my bride; you*ld have captivated my heart with one glance of your eyes, with*ld one jewel of your necklace.
How*ln beautiful is your love, my sister, my bride! How*ld much better is your love than wine, and*ld the fragrance of your oils than any spice!
Your*ln lips drip nectar, my bride; honey*ld and milk are under your tongue; the*ld fragrance of your garments is like the fragrance of Lebanon.
A*ln garden locked is my sister, my bride, a*ld spring locked, a fountain sealed.
Your*ln shoots are an orchard of pomegranates with*ld all choicest fruits, henna*ld with nard,
nard*ln and saffron, calamus and cinnamon, with*ld all trees of frankincense, myrrh*ln and aloes, with*ld all choice spices—
a*ln garden fountain, a well of living water, and*ld flowing streams from Lebanon.
Awake,*pn O north wind, and*ld come, O south wind! Blow*ln upon my garden, let*ld its spices flow.
Together in the Garden of Love
She
Let*pn my beloved come to his garden, and*ld eat its choicest fruits.
Song of Solomon 5
He
I*pn came to my garden, my sister, my bride, I*ld gathered my myrrh with my spice, I*ld ate my honeycomb with my honey, I*ld drank my wine with my milk.
Others
Eat,*pn friends, drink, and*ld be drunk with love!
The Bride Searches for Her Beloved
She

I*pn slept, but my heart was awake. A*ln sound! My beloved is knocking. “Open*ln to me, my sister, my love, my*ld dove, my perfect one, for*ln my head is wet with dew, my*ld locks with the drops of the night.”
I*ln had put off my garment; how*ld could I put it on? I*ln had bathed my feet; how*ld could I soil them?
My*ln beloved put his hand to the latch, and*ld my heart was thrilled within me.
I*ln arose to open to my beloved, and*ld my hands dripped with myrrh, my*ln fingers with liquid myrrh, on*ld the handles of the bolt.
I*ln opened to my beloved, but*ld my beloved had turned and gone. My*ln soul failed me when he spoke. I*ln sought him, but found him not; I*ld called him, but he gave no answer.
The*ln watchmen found me as*ld they went about in the city; they*ln beat me, they bruised me, they*ld took away my veil, those*ld watchmen of the walls.
I*ln adjure you, O daughters of Jerusalem, if*ld you find my beloved, that*ln you tell him I*ld am sick with love.
Others
What*pn is your beloved more than another beloved, O*ld most beautiful among women? What*ln is your beloved more than another beloved, that*ld you thus adjure us?
The Bride Praises Her Beloved
She
My*pn beloved is radiant and ruddy, distinguished*ld among ten thousand.
His*ln head is the finest gold; his*ld locks are wavy, black*ld as a raven.
His*ln eyes are like doves beside*ld streams of water, bathed*ln in milk, sitting*ld beside a full pool.
His*ln cheeks are like beds of spices, mounds*ld of sweet-smelling herbs. His*ln lips are lilies, dripping*ld liquid myrrh.
His*ln arms are rods of gold, set*ld with jewels. His*ln body is polished ivory, bedecked*ld with sapphires.
His*ln legs are alabaster columns, set*ld on bases of gold. His*ln appearance is like Lebanon, choice*ld as the cedars.
His*ln mouth is most sweet, and*ld he is altogether desirable. This*ln is my beloved and this is my friend, O*ld daughters of Jerusalem.
Song of Solomon 6
Others
Where*pn has your beloved gone, O*ld most beautiful among women? Where*ln has your beloved turned, that*ld we may seek him with you?
Together in the Garden of Love
She
My*pn beloved has gone down to his garden to*ld the beds of spices, to*ln graze in the gardens and*ld to gather lilies.
I*ln am my beloved’s and my beloved is mine; he*ld grazes among the lilies.
Solomon and His Bride Delight in Each Other
He
You*pn are beautiful as Tirzah, my love, lovely*ld as Jerusalem, awesome*ld as an army with banners.
Turn*ln away your eyes from me, for*ld they overwhelm me— Your*ln hair is like a flock of goats leaping*ld down the slopes of Gilead.
Your*ln teeth are like a flock of ewes that*ld have come up from the washing; all*ln of them bear twins; not*ld one among them has lost its young.
Your*ln cheeks are like halves of a pomegranate behind*ld your veil.
There*ln are sixty queens and eighty concubines, and*ld virgins without number.

My*ln dove, my perfect one, is the only one, the*ld only one of her mother, pure*ld to her who bore her. The*ln young women saw her and called her blessed; the*ld queens and concubines also, and they praised her.
“Who*pn is this who looks down like the dawn, beautiful*ld as the moon, bright as the sun, awesome*ld as an army with banners?”
She
I*pn went down to the nut orchard to*ld look at the blossoms of the valley, to*ln see whether the vines had budded, whether*ld the pomegranates were in bloom.
Before*ln I was aware, my desire set me among*ld the chariots of my kinsman, a prince.
Others
Return,*pn return, O Shulammite, return,*ld return, that we may look upon you.
He
Why*pn should you look upon the Shulammite, as*ld upon a dance before two armies?
Song of Solomon 7
How*pn beautiful are your feet in sandals, O*ld noble daughter! Your*ln rounded thighs are like jewels, the*ld work of a master hand.
Your*ln navel is a rounded bowl that*ld never lacks mixed wine. Your*ln belly is a heap of wheat, encircled*ld with lilies.
Your*ln two breasts are like two fawns, twins*ld of a gazelle.
Your*ln neck is like an ivory tower. Your*ln eyes are pools in Heshbon, by*ld the gate of Bath-rabbim. Your*ln nose is like a tower of Lebanon, which*ld looks toward Damascus.
Your*ln head crowns you like Carmel, and*ld your flowing locks are like purple; a*ld king is held captive in the tresses.
How*pn beautiful and pleasant you are, O*ld loved one, with all your delights!
Your*ln stature is like a palm tree, and*ld your breasts are like its clusters.
I*ln say I will climb the palm tree and*ld lay hold of its fruit. Oh*ln may your breasts be like clusters of the vine, and*ld the scent of your breath like apples,
and*ln your mouth like the best wine.
She
It*pn goes down smoothly for my beloved, gliding*ld over lips and teeth.
I*pn am my beloved’s, and*ld his desire is for me.
The Bride Gives Her Love
Come,*pn my beloved, let*ld us go out into the fields and*ld lodge in the villages;
let*ln us go out early to the vineyards and*ld see whether the vines have budded, whether*ln the grape blossoms have opened and*ld the pomegranates are in bloom. There*ln I will give you my love.
The*ln mandrakes give forth fragrance, and*ld beside our doors are all choice fruits, new*ln as well as old, which*ld I have laid up for you, O my beloved.
Song of Solomon 8
Longing for Her Beloved
Oh*pn that you were like a brother to me who*ld nursed at my mother’s breasts! If*ln I found you outside, I would kiss you, and*ld none would despise me.
I*ln would lead you and bring you into*ld the house of my mother— she*ld who used to teach me. I*ln would give you spiced wine to drink, the*ld juice of my pomegranate.
His*ln left hand is under my head, and*ld his right hand embraces me!
I*ln adjure you, O daughters of Jerusalem, that*ld you not stir up or awaken love until*ld it pleases.
Who*pn is that coming up from the wilderness, leaning*ld on her beloved? Under*pn the apple tree I awakened you. There*ln your mother was in labor with you; there*ld she who bore you was in labor.

Set*pn me as a seal upon your heart, as*ld a seal upon your arm, for*ln love is strong as death, jealousy*ld is fierce as the grave. Its*ln flashes are flashes of fire, the*ld very flame of the Lord.*s
Many*ln waters cannot quench love, neither*ld can floods drown it. If*ln a man offered for love all*ld the wealth of his house, he*ld would be utterly despised.
Final Advice
Others
We*pn have a little sister, and*ld she has no breasts. What*ln shall we do for our sister on*ld the day when she is spoken for?
If*ln she is a wall, we*ld will build on her a battlement of silver, but*ln if she is a door, we*ld will enclose her with boards of cedar.
She
I*pn was a wall, and*ld my breasts were like towers; then*ln I was in his eyes as*ld one who finds peace.
Solomon*pn had a vineyard at Baal-hamon; he*ld let out the vineyard to keepers; each*ld one was to bring for its fruit a thousand pieces of silver.
My*ln vineyard, my very own, is before me; you,*ld O Solomon, may have the thousand, and*ld the keepers of the fruit two hundred.
He
O*pn you who dwell in the gardens, with*ld companions listening for your voice; let*ld me hear it.
She
Make*pn haste, my beloved, and*ld be like a gazelle or*ln a young stag on*ld the mountains of spices.
